column2: Yours respectfully
column3: Yours respectfully

column2: J.W. DUNGY.
column3: j w DUNGY.

column2: BRANTFORD, C.W., JANUARY 11th, 61.
column3: BRANTFORD, c w, january eleventh sixty one.

column2: MR.
column3: mr

column2: WM.
column3: w m.

column2: STILL, DEAR SIR:--I take this opportunity to drop you a few lines to let you hear from me.
column3: STILL, DEAR SIR:--I take this opportunity to drop you a few lines to let you hear from me.

column2: I am well at this time, hoping this will find you the same.
column3: I am well at this time, hoping this will find you the same.

column2: I acknowledge my great neglectness of you with great regret that I have not answered your letter before this, I hope you will excuse me as I have succeeded in getting me a wife since I wrote to you last.
column3: I acknowledge my great neglectness of you with great regret that I have not answered your letter before this, I hope you will excuse me as I have succeeded in getting me a wife since I wrote to you last.

column2: My mind has been much taken up in so doing for several months past.
column3: My mind has been much taken up in so doing for several months past.

column2: Give my compliments to your wife and your family, and Mr. Gibbs, also hoping they are all well.
column3: Give my compliments to your wife and your family, and mr Gibbs, also hoping they are all well.

column2: Tell Mrs. Still to pray for me that I may grow in grace and the knowledge of the truth as it is in Jesus.
column3: Tell mrs Still to pray for me that I may grow in grace and the knowledge of the truth as it is in Jesus.

column2: I often think of you all.
column3: I often think of you all.

column2: I pray that the time may come when we will all be men in the United States.
column3: I pray that the time may come when we will all be men in the United States.

column2: We have read here of the great disturbance in the South.
column3: We have read here of the great disturbance in the South.

column2: My prayer is that this may be a deathblow to Slavery.
column3: My prayer is that this may be a deathblow to Slavery.

column2: Do you ever have any Underground Rail Road passengers now?
column3: Do you ever have any Underground Rail Road passengers now?

column2: Times have been very prosperous in Canada this year.
column3: Times have been very prosperous in Canada this year.

column2: The commercial trade and traffic on the railways has been very dull for these few months back.
column3: The commercial trade and traffic on the railways has been very dull for these few months back.

column2: Business on the Buffalo and Lake Huron railway has been so dull that a great number of the hands have been discharged on account of the panic in the South.
column3: Business on the Buffalo and Lake Huron railway has been so dull that a great number of the hands have been discharged on account of the panic in the South.

column2: Canada yet cries, Freedom!
column3: Canada yet cries, Freedom!

column2: Freedom!
column3: Freedom!

column2: Freedom!
column3: Freedom!

column2: I must now say a little about my friend and brother Stepney Brown, he lived about six months at the Niagara Falls and is now going to school here in Brantford, he sends his best respects to you all.
column3: I must now say a little about my friend and brother Stepney Brown, he lived about six months at the Niagara Falls and is now going to school here in Brantford, he sends his best respects to you all.

column2: He and I often sit together at night after the labor of the day is over talking about our absent friends wishing we could see them once more.
column3: He and I often sit together at night after the labor of the day is over talking about our absent friends wishing we could see them once more.

column2: Mr. Brown and myself have been wishing for one or two of your slavery standards and would be much obliged to you if you would send some of the latest.
column3: mr Brown and myself have been wishing for one or two of your slavery standards and would be much obliged to you if you would send some of the latest.

column2: Please let me hear from you as soon as possible.
column3: Please let me hear from you as soon as possible.

column2: I must now bring my letter to a close and remain your affectionate friend,
column3: I must now bring my letter to a close and remain your affectionate friend,

column2: J.W. DUNGY.
column3: j w DUNGY.

column2: P.S. May the Lord be with you.
column3: p s May the Lord be with you.

column2: J.W. DUNGY.
column3: j w DUNGY.

column2: Address your letter to John W. Dungy, Brantford, C.W.
column3: Address your letter to john w Dungy, Brantford, c w

column2: AUNT HANNAH MOORE.
column3: AUNT HANNAH MOORE.

column2: In 1854 in company with her so-called Mistress (Mary Moore) Aunt Hannah arrived in Philadelphia, from Missouri, being _en route_ to California, where she with her mistress was to join her master, who had gone there years before to seek his fortune.
column3: In eighteen fifty four in company with her so-called Mistress (Mary Moore) Aunt Hannah arrived in Philadelphia, from Missouri, being underscore en route underscore to California, where she with her mistress was to join her master, who had gone there years before to seek his fortune.

column2: The mistress having relatives in this city tarried here a short time, not doubting that she had sufficient control over Aunt Hannah to keep her from contact with either abolitionists or those of her own color, and that she would have no difficulty in taking her with her to her journey's end.
column3: The mistress having relatives in this city tarried here a short time, not doubting that she had sufficient control over Aunt Hannah to keep her from contact with either abolitionists or those of her own color, and that she would have no difficulty in taking her with her to her journey's end.

column2: If such were her calculations she was greatly mistaken.
column3: If such were her calculations she was greatly mistaken.

column2: For although Aunt Hannah was destitute of book-learning she was nevertheless a woman of thought and natural ability, and while she wisely kept her counsel from her mistress she took care to make her wants known to an abolitionist.
column3: For although Aunt Hannah was destitute of book learning she was nevertheless a woman of thought and natural ability, and while she wisely kept her counsel from her mistress she took care to make her wants known to an abolitionist.

column2: She had passed many years under the yoke, under different owners, and now seeing a ray of hope she availed herself of the opportunity to secure her freedom. She had occasion to go to a store in the neighborhood where she was stopping, and to her unspeakable joy she found the proprietor an abolitionist and a friend who inquired into her condition and proffered her assistance.
column3: She had passed many years under the yoke, under different owners, and now seeing a ray of hope she availed herself of the opportunity to secure her freedom. She had occasion to go to a store in the neighborhood where she was stopping, and to her unspeakable joy she found the proprietor an abolitionist and a friend who inquired into her condition and proffered her assistance.

column2: The store-keeper quickly made known her condition at the Anti-slavery Office, and in double-quick time J.M.
column3: The store keeper quickly made known her condition at the Anti slavery Office, and in double quick time j m

column2: McKim and Charles Wise as abolitionists and members of the Vigilance Committee repaired to the stopping-place of the mistress and her slave to demand in the name of humanity and the laws of Pennsylvania that Aunt Hannah should be no longer held in fetters but that she should be immediately proclaimed free.
column3: McKim and Charles Wise as abolitionists and members of the Vigilance Committee repaired to the stopping place of the mistress and her slave to demand in the name of humanity and the laws of Pennsylvania that Aunt Hannah should be no longer held in fetters but that she should be immediately proclaimed free.

column2: In the eyes of the mistress this procedure was so extraordinary that she became very much excited and for a moment threatened them with the "broomstick," but her raving had no effect on Messrs.
column3: In the eyes of the mistress this procedure was so extraordinary that she became very much excited and for a moment threatened them with the "broomstick," but her raving had no effect on Messrs.

column2: McKim and Wise, who did not rest contented until Aunt Hannah was safely in their hands.
column3: McKim and Wise, who did not rest contented until Aunt Hannah was safely in their hands.

column2: She had lived a slave in Moore's family in the State of Missouri about ten years and said she was treated very well, had plenty to eat, plenty to wear, and a plenty of work.
column3: She had lived a slave in Moore's family in the State of Missouri about ten years and said she was treated very well, had plenty to eat, plenty to wear, and a plenty of work.

column2: It was prior to her coming into the possession of Moore that Aunt Hannah had been made to drink the bitter waters of oppression.
column3: It was prior to her coming into the possession of Moore that Aunt Hannah had been made to drink the bitter waters of oppression.

column2: From this point, therefore, we shall present some of the incidents of her life, from infancy, and very nearly word for word as she related them:
column3: From this point, therefore, we shall present some of the incidents of her life, from infancy, and very nearly word for word as she related them:

column2: Moore bought me from a man named McCaully, who owned me about a year.	Moore bought me from a man named McCaully, who owned me about a year.
column3: true

column2: I fared dreadful bad under McCaully.
column3: I fared dreadful bad under McCaully.

column2: One day in a rage he undertook to beat me with the limb of a cherry-tree; he began at me and tried in the first place to snatch my clothes off, but he did not succeed.
column3: One day in a rage he undertook to beat me with the limb of a cherry tree; he began at me and tried in the first place to snatch my clothes off, but he did not succeed.

column2: After that he beat the cherry-tree limb all to pieces over me.
column3: After that he beat the cherry tree limb all to pieces over me.

column2: The first blow struck me on the back of my neck and knocked me down; his wife was looking on, sitting on the side of the bed crying to him to lay on. After the limb was worn out he then went out to the yard and got a lath, and he come at me again and beat me with that until he broke it all to pieces.
column3: The first blow struck me on the back of my neck and knocked me down; his wife was looking on, sitting on the side of the bed crying to him to lay on. After the limb was worn out he then went out to the yard and got a lath, and he come at me again and beat me with that until he broke it all to pieces.

column2: He was not satisfied then; he next went to the fence and tore off a paling, and with that he took both hands, 'cursing' me all the time as hard as he could.
column3: He was not satisfied then; he next went to the fence and tore off a paling, and with that he took both hands, 'cursing' me all the time as hard as he could.

column2: With an oath he would say, 'now don't you love me?' 'Oh master, I will pray for you, I would cry, then he would 'cuss' harder than ever.' He beat me until he was tired and quit.
column3: With an oath he would say, 'now don't you love me?' 'Oh master, I will pray for you, I would cry, then he would 'cuss' harder than ever.' He beat me until he was tired and quit.

column2: I crept out of doors and throwed up blood; some days I was hardly able to creep. With this beating I was laid up several weeks.
column3: I crept out of doors and throwed up blood; some days I was hardly able to creep. With this beating I was laid up several weeks.

column2: Another time Mistress McCaully got very angry.
column3: Another time Mistress McCaully got very angry.

column2: One day she beat me as bad as he did.
column3: One day she beat me as bad as he did.

column2: She was a woman who would get very mad in a minute.
column3: She was a woman who would get very mad in a minute.

column2: One day she began scolding and said the kitchen wasn't kept clean.
column3: One day she began scolding and said the kitchen wasn't kept clean.

column2: I told her the kitchen was kept as clean as any kitchen in the place; she spoke very angry, and said she didn't go by other folks but she had rules of her own.
column3: I told her the kitchen was kept as clean as any kitchen in the place; she spoke very angry, and said she didn't go by other folks but she had rules of her own.

column2: She soon ordered me to come in to her.
column3: She soon ordered me to come in to her.

column2: I went in as she ordered me; she met me with a mule-rope, and ordered me to cross my hands.
column3: I went in as she ordered me; she met me with a mule rope, and ordered me to cross my hands.

column2: I crossed my hands and she tied me to the bedstead.
column3: I crossed my hands and she tied me to the bedstead.

column2: Here her husband said, 'my dear, now let me do the fighting.' In her mad fit she said he shouldn't do it, and told him to stand back and keep out of the way or I will give you the cowhide she said to him.
column3: Here her husband said, 'my dear, now let me do the fighting.' In her mad fit she said he shouldn't do it, and told him to stand back and keep out of the way or I will give you the cowhide she said to him.

column2: He then 'sot' down in a 'cheer' and looked like a man condemned to be hung; then she whipped me with the cowhide until I sunk to the floor.
column3: He then 'sot' down in a 'cheer' and looked like a man condemned to be hung; then she whipped me with the cowhide until I sunk to the floor.

column2: He then begged her to quit.
column3: He then begged her to quit.

column2: He said to his wife she has begged and begged and you have whipped her enough.
column3: He said to his wife she has begged and begged and you have whipped her enough.

column2: She only raged 'wus;' she turned the butt end of the cowhide and struck me five or six blows over my head as hard as she could; she then throwed the cowhide down and told a little girl to untie me.
column3: She only raged 'wus;' she turned the butt end of the cowhide and struck me five or six blows over my head as hard as she could; she then throwed the cowhide down and told a little girl to untie me.

column2: The little girl was not able to do it; Mr. McCaully then untied me himself.
column3: The little girl was not able to do it; mr McCaully then untied me himself.

column2: Both times that I was beat the blood run down from my head to my feet.
column3: Both times that I was beat the blood run down from my head to my feet.

column2: They wouldn't give you anything to eat hardly.	They wouldn't give you anything to eat hardly.
column3: true

column2: McCaully bore the name of coming by free colored children without buying them, and selling them afterwards.
column3: McCaully bore the name of coming by free colored children without buying them, and selling them afterwards.

column2: One boy on the place always said that he was free but had been kidnapped from Arkansas.
column3: One boy on the place always said that he was free but had been kidnapped from Arkansas.

column2: He could tell all about how he was kidnapped, but could not find anybody to do anything for him, so he had to content himself.
column3: He could tell all about how he was kidnapped, but could not find anybody to do anything for him, so he had to content himself.

column2: McCaully bought me from a man by the name of Landers.	McCaully bought me from a man by the name of Landers.
column3: true

column2: While in Landers' hands I had the rheumatism and was not able to work.
column3: While in Landers' hands I had the rheumatism and was not able to work.

column2: He was afraid I was going to die, or he would lose me, and I would not be of any service to him, so he took and traded me off for a wagon.
column3: He was afraid I was going to die, or he would lose me, and I would not be of any service to him, so he took and traded me off for a wagon.

column2: I was something better when he traded me off; well enough to be about.
column3: I was something better when he traded me off; well enough to be about.

column2: My health remained bad for about four years, and I never got my health until Moore bought me. Moore took me for a debt.
column3: My health remained bad for about four years, and I never got my health until Moore bought me. Moore took me for a debt.

column2: McCaully owed Moore for wagons.
column3: McCaully owed Moore for wagons.

column2: I was not born in Missouri but was born in Virginia.
column3: I was not born in Missouri but was born in Virginia.

column2: From my earliest memory I was owned by Conrad Hackler; he lived in Grason County.
column3: From my earliest memory I was owned by Conrad Hackler; he lived in Grason County.

column2: He was a very poor man, and had no other slave but me.
column3: He was a very poor man, and had no other slave but me.

column2: He bought me before I was quite four years old, for one hundred dollars.
column3: He bought me before I was quite four years old, for one hundred dollars.

column2: Hackler bought me from a man named William Scott.
column3: Hackler bought me from a man named William Scott.

column2: I must go back by good rights to the beginning and tell all: Scott bought me first from a young man he met one day in the road, with a bundle in his arms.
column3: I must go back by good rights to the beginning and tell all: Scott bought me first from a young man he met one day in the road, with a bundle in his arms.

column2: Scott, wishing to know of the young man what he had in his bundle, was told that he had a baby.
column3: Scott, wishing to know of the young man what he had in his bundle, was told that he had a baby.

column2: 'What are you going to do with it?' said Scott.
column3: 'What are you going to do with it?' said Scott.

column2: The young man said that he was going to take it to his sister; that its mother was dead, and it had nobody to take care of it.
column3: The young man said that he was going to take it to his sister; that its mother was dead, and it had nobody to take care of it.

column2: Scott offered the young man a horse for it, and the young man took him up.
column3: Scott offered the young man a horse for it, and the young man took him up.

column2: This is the way I was told that Scott came by me.
column3: This is the way I was told that Scott came by me.

column2: I never knowed anything about my mother or father, but I have always believed that my mother was a white woman, and that I was put away to save her character; I have always thought this.
column3: I never knowed anything about my mother or father, but I have always believed that my mother was a white woman, and that I was put away to save her character; I have always thought this.

column2: Under Hackler I was treated more like a brute than a human being.
column3: Under Hackler I was treated more like a brute than a human being.

column2: I was fed like the dogs; had a trough dug out of a piece of wood for a plate.
column3: I was fed like the dogs; had a trough dug out of a piece of wood for a plate.

column2: After I growed up to ten years old they made me sleep out in an old house standing off some distance from the main house where my master and mistress lived.
column3: After I growed up to ten years old they made me sleep out in an old house standing off some distance from the main house where my master and mistress lived.

column2: A bed of straw and old rags was made for me in a big trough called the tan trough (a trough having been used for tanning purposes).
column3: A bed of straw and old rags was made for me in a big trough called the tan trough (a trough having been used for tanning purposes).

column2: The cats about the place came and slept with me, and was all the company I had.
column3: The cats about the place came and slept with me, and was all the company I had.

column2: I had to work with the hoe in the field and help do everything in doors and out in all weathers.
column3: I had to work with the hoe in the field and help do everything in doors and out in all weathers.

column2: The place was so poor that some seasons he would not raise twenty bushels of corn and hardly three bushels of wheat.
column3: The place was so poor that some seasons he would not raise twenty bushels of corn and hardly three bushels of wheat.

column2: As for shoes I never knowed what it was to have a pair of shoes until I was grown up.
column3: As for shoes I never knowed what it was to have a pair of shoes until I was grown up.

column2: After I growed up to be a woman my master thought nothing of taking my clothes off, and would whip me until the blood would run down to the ground.
column3: After I growed up to be a woman my master thought nothing of taking my clothes off, and would whip me until the blood would run down to the ground.

column2: After I was twenty-five years old they did not treat me so bad; they both professed to get religion about that time; and my master said he would never lay the weight of his finger on me again. Once after that mistress wanted him to whip me, but he didn't do it, nor never whipped me any more.
column3: After I was twenty five years old they did not treat me so bad; they both professed to get religion about that time; and my master said he would never lay the weight of his finger on me again. Once after that mistress wanted him to whip me, but he didn't do it, nor never whipped me any more.

column2: After awhile my master died; if they had gone according to law I would have been hired out or sold, but my mistress wanted to keep me to carry on the place for her support.
column3: After awhile my master died; if they had gone according to law I would have been hired out or sold, but my mistress wanted to keep me to carry on the place for her support.

column2: So I was kept for seven or eight years after his death.
column3: So I was kept for seven or eight years after his death.

column2: It was understood between my mistress, and her children, and her friends, who all met after master died, that I was to take care of mistress, and after mistress died I should not serve anybody else.
column3: It was understood between my mistress, and her children, and her friends, who all met after master died, that I was to take care of mistress, and after mistress died I should not serve anybody else.

column2: I done my best to keep my mistress from suffering.
column3: I done my best to keep my mistress from suffering.

column2: After a few years they all became dissatisfied, and moved to Missouri.
column3: After a few years they all became dissatisfied, and moved to Missouri.

column2: They scattered, and took up government land.
column3: They scattered, and took up government land.

column2: Without means they lived as poor people commonly live, on small farms in the woods.
column3: Without means they lived as poor people commonly live, on small farms in the woods.

column2: I still lived with my mistress.
column3: I still lived with my mistress.

column2: Some of the heirs got dissatisfied, and sued for their rights or a settlement; then I was sold with my child, a boy."
column3: Some of the heirs got dissatisfied, and sued for their rights or a settlement; then I was sold with my child, a boy."

column2: Thus Aunt Hannah reviewed her slave-life, showing that she had been in the hands of six different owners, and had seen great tribulation under each of them, except the last; that she had never known a mother's or a father's care; that Slavery had given her one child, but no husband as a protector or a father.
column3: Thus Aunt Hannah reviewed her slave life, showing that she had been in the hands of six different owners, and had seen great tribulation under each of them, except the last; that she had never known a mother's or a father's care; that Slavery had given her one child, but no husband as a protector or a father.

column2: The half of what she passed through in the way of suffering has scarcely been hinted at in this sketch.
column3: The half of what she passed through in the way of suffering has scarcely been hinted at in this sketch.

column2: Fifty-seven years were passed in bondage before she reached Philadelphia.
column3: Fifty seven years were passed in bondage before she reached Philadelphia.

column2: Under the good Providence through which she came in possession of her freedom, she found a kind home with a family of Abolitionists, (Mrs.
column3: Under the good Providence through which she came in possession of her freedom, she found a kind home with a family of Abolitionists, (mrs

column2: Gillingham's), whose hearts had been in deep sympathy with the slave for many years.
column3: Gillingham's), whose hearts had been in deep sympathy with the slave for many years.

column2: In this situation Aunt Hannah remained several years, honest, faithful, and obliging, taking care of her earnings, which were put out at interest for her by her friends.
column3: In this situation Aunt Hannah remained several years, honest, faithful, and obliging, taking care of her earnings, which were put out at interest for her by her friends.

column2: Her mind was deeply imbued with religious feeling, and an unshaken confidence in God as her only trust; she connected herself with the A.M.E.
column3: Her mind was deeply imbued with religious feeling, and an unshaken confidence in God as her only trust; she connected herself with the a m e

column2: Bethel Church, of Philadelphia, where she has walked, blameless and exemplary up to this day.
column3: Bethel Church, of Philadelphia, where she has walked, blameless and exemplary up to this day.

column2: Probably there is not a member in that large congregation whose simple faith and whose walk and conversation are more commendable than Aunt Hannah's.
column3: Probably there is not a member in that large congregation whose simple faith and whose walk and conversation are more commendable than Aunt Hannah's.

column2: Although she has passed through so many hardships she is a woman of good judgment and more than average intellect; enjoys good health, vigor, and peace of mind in her old days, with a small income just sufficient to meet her humble wants without having to live at service.
column3: Although she has passed through so many hardships she is a woman of good judgment and more than average intellect; enjoys good health, vigor, and peace of mind in her old days, with a small income just sufficient to meet her humble wants without having to live at service.

column2: After living in Philadelphia for several years, she was married to a man of about her own age, possessing all her good qualities; had served a life-time in a highly respectable Quaker family of this city, and had so won the esteem of his kind employer that at his death he left him a comfortable house for life, so that he was not under the necessity of serving another.
column3: After living in Philadelphia for several years, she was married to a man of about her own age, possessing all her good qualities; had served a life time in a highly respectable Quaker family of this city, and had so won the esteem of his kind employer that at his death he left him a comfortable house for life, so that he was not under the necessity of serving another.

column2: The name of the recipient of the good Quaker friend's bounty and Aunt Hannah's companion, was Thomas Todd.
column3: The name of the recipient of the good Quaker friend's bounty and Aunt Hannah's companion, was Thomas Todd.

column2: After a few years of wedded life, Aunt Hannah was called upon to be left alone again in the world by the death of her husband, whose loss was mourned by many friends, both colored and white, who knew and respected him.
column3: After a few years of wedded life, Aunt Hannah was called upon to be left alone again in the world by the death of her husband, whose loss was mourned by many friends, both colored and white, who knew and respected him.
